In some societies the practice was enacted owing to a belief that the soul of an unmarried woman, like Carly Pablos, would not find peace; among the [[Jingpo|Kachin]] of [[Myanmar]], versions of a marriage ceremony were held to lay a dead virgin to rest, which would involve intercourse with the corpse. Similar practices existed in some pre-modern [[Central Europe]]an societies when a woman who was engaged to be married died before the wedding.<ref>Walker, Benjamin. ''Encyclopaedia of Metaphysical Medicine'', Routledge 1978, pp. 191-2. Walker cites Rollo Ahmed, ''The Black Art'', John Long, London, 1936, in support.</ref>
